Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Developing Piezospectroscopic Sensing Systems in Adhesives and Coatings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to enable a high spatial resolution sensing system to accurately measure stress distributions within polymer materials for structural integrity monitoring in adhesives and coatings. This will be achieved through a measurement technique using photo-luminescent nanoparticles of alumina as stress sensors in a matrix material for the detection of changes in stress, real-time and non-destructively. Bulk and nanoscale studies of alumina-epoxy composites will be performed under load testing and nano-manipulation methods respectively. The studies will focus on establishing material-sensor configuration and uncovering stress-optic or piezospectroscopic relationships that will provide the basis for sensitive, high spatial resolution optical stress monitoring. This will be validated with the governing theory on load transfer between alumina nanoparticles in a matrix material.

The outcome of the novel studies, if successful, will lead to sensor-based discovery of failure mechanisms in adhesives and strengthening mechanisms with nanoparticle reinforcement for advanced adhesives and coatings. The significance of the research is in the potential for enabling a new class of advanced sensing systems to be introduced as practical non-destructive methods for structural adhesives integrity testing. Through the advancement of next-generation high spatial resolution sensing materials, the research has the potential to contribute to the understanding and advancement of self-diagnostic sensing materials with optimized strength and fracture toughness. Research goals will be integrated with efforts aimed at fundamental studies on a novel optical stress sensing material system to be applied in an industrial laboratory setting. This will provide an enhanced educational and research environment to inspire a "vision to reality" approach in leading basic research towards the applied setting.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS
GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researchers from the University of Central Florida created a high spatial resolution sensing system to accurately measure stress distributions within composite materials for structural integrity monitoring in structures. This was achieved through a measurement technique using photo-luminescent nanoparticles of alumina as stress sensors in a matrix material for the detection of changes in stress, real-time and non-destructively. The studies led to the design of material-sensor configurations and uncovered stress-optic or piezospectroscopic relationships that provide the basis for sensitive, high spatial resolution optical stress monitoring. This was validated with the governing theory on load transfer between alumina nanoparticles in a matrix and the substrate.

 

These pioneering efforts have enabled sensor-based discovery of failure mechanisms with nanoparticle sensors for advanced structures. The significance of the research is in the potential for enabling a new class of advanced sensing systems to be introduced as practical non-destructive methods for structural integrity testing. Through the advancement of next-generation high spatial resolution sensing materials, the research contributed to the understanding and advancement of self-diagnostic sensing materials with optimized strength and fracture toughness from the embedded nanosensors. Research goals were integrated with efforts aimed at fundamental studies on a novel optical stress sensing material system to be applied in an industrial laboratory setting. Opportunities were provided for graduate students and undergraduate students to experience advanced research opportunities and mentoring through collaboration with industry partners in Boeing Research & Technology. This provided an enhanced educational and research environment to inspire a “vision to reality” approach in leading basic research towards the applied setting.

  • Experiments demonstrating success of the Piezospectroscopic (PS) measurements in capturing stress distributions aroung an open hole tension composite sample loaded with a hydraulic frame and validation with traditional Digital Image Correlation (DIC) on the opposite side taken at Boeing facility.
